fullText: This new staging of 'The Color Purple' is far more successful than the original 2005 Broadway production, thanks in large part to John Doyle's stripped-down direction and a cast that brings fresh vitality to Alice Walker's story.

bwwExcerpt: Speaking of commodity musicals, 'The Color Purple,' first seen on Broadway 10 years ago, is now being revived there in a brand-new production directed by John Doyle and imported from the Menier Chocolate Factory, one of London's trendiest venues. Any way you stage it, the musical version of the film version of Alice Walker's novel is an exercise in treacly feel-good sentimentality, but Mr. Doyle's scaled-down, ruthlessly cut version makes the best possible case for 'The Color Purple.' He has turned it into a concert-style let-us-tell-you-a-story show whose only set pieces are wooden chairs and woven baskets, in the process stripping away all the whiz-bang aspects of Gary Griffin's 2005 staging, which now appear in retrospect to have obscured the virtues (such as they are) of 'The Color Purple.'
